newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan forex market shaky as dollar deposits ebb.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan forex market shaky as dollar deposits ebb.

text.p: Pakistani forward dollar rates surged to record highs on Wednesday amid reports of heavy withdrawals from foreign exchange accounts prompted by economic jitters putting pressure on the rupee, dealers said.

"Record forward rates for the dollar amid an unprecedented shortage of the U.S. currency in the market suggest that banks see the rupee weakening further in the coming months," forex dealer Salman Arshad of ABN Amro Bank told Reuters.
Dealers said offers for six-month forward dollars opened at 40.70 rupees on Wednesday in the interbank forex market against Tuesday's closing rate of 40.50 rupees and Monday's 40.15.
Forward rates have been rising since the State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) devalued the rupee 3.79 percent against the dollar on September 10, they said.
The six-month forward rate for the dollar was 39.25 rupees before the devaluation, a premium of about 5.6 percent. Within a week it had risen to around 40 rupees, Arshad said.
Breaking a pattern of gradual downward adjustments, the SBP cut its rate sharply on September 10 to 36.9700/37.1549 to the dollar from 35.6200/35.7981 fixed on August 29.
"The devaluation should have been enough to reduce the differential between the official and unofficial dollar rates, but the market doesn't seem to agree," a Western economist said.

The devaluation sparked rumours -- officially denied -- that the government might freeze foreign currency deposits to help boost its depleting foreign reserves, which stood at $2.34 billion in August against $2.82 billion in August 1995.
Individuals, not trusting central bank denials, have since pulled about $200 million from forex bank accounts, bankers say.
"The historically sharp rise in the premium on forward dollar buying indicates that the market is not only short of dollars but has lost confidence in the rupee," Arshad said.

Dealers said the erosion of the rupee, which has lost 5.31 percent of its dollar value since July 1 and 7.95 percent since January 1, had weakened the confidence of importers who are heavily buying forward dollars to hedge their positions.
A foreign banker, who asked not to be named, said the market was anticipating a further loss of up to four percent in the rupee's value against the dollar by the end of 1996.
Dealers said economic worries had intensified after Moody's Investors Service Inc put Pakistan's credit ratings under review on Monday for possible downgrading.

Moody's said it may cut Pakistan's B1 long-term foreign currency rating and its B2 sovereign ceiling for foreign currency deposits. Pakistan's B1-rated foreign currency bonds and notes were also placed on review for possible downgrade.

It voiced concern at "Pakistan's weakening macroeconomic fundamentals, as evidenced by the deviations from longstanding goals of economic restructuring, as well as increased levels of short-term debt and ongoing balance of payments difficulties."
The chief dealer at one brokerage house said Pakistan faced loan repayments of around $700 million in October and had an average monthly trade deficit of $250 million.
"What will be the reserves positions after the October loan payments if the International Monetary Fund (IMF) refuses to release the suspended standby facility?" he asked.
Pakistani officials have taken undisclosed new proposals to Washington this week to try to convince the IMF to reactivate the $600 million standby loan, stalled for the past six months.
The dealer said only a positive outcome of the Washington visit could prevent the crisis from worsening.
